title: Schoolgirl bullied for her 'individual style' grows up into an award-winning stylist
text:

They say your school days are supposed to be the best of your life - but that's definitely not the case for Susie Hasler.

The 36-year-old, from East Grinstead, West Sussex, admits she was an awkward schoolgirl.

But she was always determined to rock her own style - something she was mercilessly bullied for.

And Susie has definitely had the last laugh as she's now an award-winning fashion stylist who is so in demand she's booked up until December 2020.

The mum-of-one, who has a seven-year-old son, Clark, with her husband Tom, has helped thousands of women improve their style and confidence.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

Susie said: "Even at primary school, I loved to look different from the other girls and I always experimented with hair accessories.

“At secondary school, the Spice Girls came along, and it gave me that push to explore my individual style - to me, they said it was OK to look different from others.

“But I was badly bullied by both boys and girls for standing out. Before I had braces, my teeth stuck out and I was picked on by the boys.

“The girls made fun of my thick, wavy hair, as Jennifer Aniston’s poker straight locks were in fashion.

“I failed maths and science at school and got Cs in everything else.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

“When I got to college, I reinvented myself, my style, became more confident, got a great group of friends and was regularly told off by the teachers for socialising more than working.

“I didn’t go to uni as I hated studying and didn’t pass my exams with good enough grades.”

After starting an admin career at 18, Susie spent the next 12 years "hating" what she did for a living.

Not only that, she was again being mocked for her sense of style.

Susie said: "It felt like I was being stifled and I felt terrified it would be my life forever. I had so much creativity and had no idea where to channel it.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

"My last job in admin was for a male-dominated engineering company. I expressed my style when I worked in the office and got ribbed regularly by the many older men I worked with."

Confessing she isn't "academically gifted" Susie feared she would fail as a businesswoman but made the brave step to quit the job she despised to strike out on her own.

By 2011 she had pulled together the £1,500 she needed to study for a diploma in personal styling at the Style Coaching Institute in 2011.

She wanted to “help women feel good about their bodies and to bring personal style to women like me”.

At 29, Susie gave birth to her son Clark and at six weeks old he caught whooping cough and almost died.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

Susie admits she found motherhood tough - and developed post-natal depression after Clark’s brush with death.

She said: "It was so hard and I felt out of my depth."

Emotionally drained, Susie knew she didn’t want to go back to work in an office so she took the leap to launch her own website, Styled By Susie .

Susie said: “I’m not from a middle-class, privileged background and have no amazing connections; and I had to work very hard.

“I used to work for free to help build up my client base. I would work Friday evenings doing group styling, until 1am, and would be in Bluewater on a Saturday morning at 9am the next day.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

“My little boy was only 18 months and it was hard!”

But her efforts paid off.

Her clients - known as her ‘tribe’ - took to Facebook to praise her personal stylist sessions, and word soon spread.

The group now boasts 11,000 women from around the world who Susie has styled - or who are waiting for sessions to become available.

Now, she only works four days a week during term-time and enjoys spending time with Clark and Tom during the school holidays.

She has also won a Best Stylist Award.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

Susie specialises in women on a budget whose bodies have changed shape - whether that’s due to motherhood, the menopause, or losing or gaining weight.

She offers face-to-face styling sessions at Bluewater shopping centre, which cost £150 for three hours.

But she's so in demand she's booked up until Christmas next year.

Susie also offers online consultations ranging from £35 to £85 to women from around the world.

She said: “I empower women to dress for their shapes as they are and to shine to their full potential.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

“I help clients of all shapes and sizes, and I work with realistic budgets and my clients like me because they can relate to me. I am not filtered, glossy or pretentious.

“In a world of Instagram fashion influencers and celebrity stylists, I like to fly the flag for real women, and offering realistic style tips on achievable and affordable budgets.”

Susies expertise have already saved one teenager from being bullied and helped her to make a bold fashion choice.

She rushed to the teenager's rescue when her own friend told her she looked "terrible".

Susie couldn't stop herself taking action when the girl's pal was even grabbing passers-by to get them to tell her how awful she looked in a pair of sunglasses.

(Image: Susie Hasler)

She was out shopping at Bluewater when she overheard the insults and decided to step in.

Susie said: ""I was in Primark and there were two girls who were trying on sunglasses.

"One of the girls - and with friends like this who needs enemies - was getting passers-by to get her friend how awful she looked.

"She was saying 'those glasses look awful, excuse me, can you tell my friend how terrible she looks'.

"I said 'excuse me, can I have a look?' She turned around and she was wearing high-fashion sunglasses, not to everyone’s taste.

"And I said 'I’m a personal stylist, and I think they look fab, and if you love them, you should get them'.

"At which point, the friend said 'I think I’m going to listen to the personal stylist’s point of view'.

"And her friend said 'but I don’t like them, I like the more classic styles'.

"I said to her, 'what about your friend? She likes these? She looks fab in them' - so she went and bought them."

And Susie has a powerful message behind her intervention.

She said: "Be careful who you surround yourself with and remember just because your friend doesn't like it doesn’t mean you don’t have to buy it.

"Follow your own style intuition. And if I’m nearby, I’ll tell them off!"
description: Susie Hasler, from West Sussex, launched her fashion blog when she was suffering from post-natal depression and is now booked up until December 2020
